title: Which has the most atoms, 1.6 g CH4, 1.7 g NH3, or 1.8 g H2O? - Quora

response.answer_text: Okay, let's see CH4 first Mass of CH4=12+4=16g Given mass=1.6g Number of moles=1.6/16=0.1 Number of atoms in 1 mole=6.022×10^23 Number of atoms in 10 moles=6.022×10^23×0.1=6.022×10^22 NOW NH3 Mass of NH3=14+3g=17g Number of moles in 1.7g of NH3=1.7/17=0.1 moles Number of atoms in given mass=6.022×10^23×0.1=6.022×10^22 Same for H2O, Number of moles in given mass=1.8/18=0.1 Number of atoms in given mass=6.022×10^23×0.1=6.022×10^22 All the compounds have same number of atoms in the given mass. For more on chemistry follow me on quora and can see my blog Chemistry for 9th 10th

It is CH4, methane, whose molecule is penta atomic. The number of molecules is the same (one-tenth of Avogadro’s number) in all the three cases as each represents 0.1 mole of the respective compound. NH3 and H2O are respectively tetra atomic and triatomic molecules. So, the number of atoms in equimolar amounts of the compounds decreases in the order CH4 > NH3 > H2O.
